project.activities: 150 families will be trained in basic business skills.

image.title: Poor women micro-enterprise development-Indonesia

project.longTermImpact: 150 poor families will take the first step out of poverty.
project.need: 35 million people in Indonesia live below the poverty line with little or no income. Indonesia is a beautiful country where both Christians and Muslims live side by side. Take Murni for example, a vulnerable woman living on an income below $2 a day. In poor villages simple illnesses like diarrhea can be fatal. When a woman has an income she can pay for medical care.
project.summary: Helping 150 poor Indonesian women in 14 villages to help themselves out of poverty by running a 3-day course with their local NGO teaching basic business skills like accounting and product packaging.
project.title: Poor women micro-enterprise development-Indonesia

project.activities: Self-sustainability is fundamental to DDD’s mission. By selling "digitization" services we generate income like a handicraft NGO sells its goods. We reinvest all of our profit into our employees’ development through college education, health care, continued training, and English lessons.

image.title: Digital Divide Data (DDD)

project.longTermImpact: The outcomes of this project include employeeing more than 100 disadvantaged people in Cambodia, allowing them to improve their lives and provide for their families.
project.need: As the world’s economy becomes increasingly interconnected, it is essential that opportunities to join the global economy exist in developing countries. To address this need, DDD was created to capitalize on the business opportunity from companies searching for lower-cost IT outsourcing solutions. DDD is at the nexus of several development themes including: technology transfer, SME development, economic alternatives to human trafficking, self sustainability and disabled individuals’ equality.
project.summary: DigitalDivideData is an IT socially conscious organization dedicated to creating new technology-related jobs for the disadvantaged. DDD currently has ninety employees and twenty contracts.
project.title: Digital Divide Data (DDD)

project.activities: The goal of the project is to supply at least one computer to every classroom in sub-Saharan Africa with Internet access if possible by 2020. Our long-term goal is to reach the most remote areas of Uganda and other African countries in later years.

image.title: Bridging the digital divide with computers

project.longTermImpact: We have sent our first 94 PCs and 6 printers in 2002 and have begun distributing them as well as providing training seminars in schools in Kampala, Uganda. We hope to expand this in coming years.
project.need: Currently U.S. businesses pay for the disposal of some twenty million low-end computers every year. Though the computer equipment is serviceable for those with less sophisticated needs, it is melted down or buried in landfills. These computers would greatly assist Africa and it's growing need for information technology. This project would affect more than 5000 primary and secondary school children per year through computer donations and training seminars.
project.summary: Reusing low-end computers from the developed world to teach disadvantaged sub-Saharan children computer skills is a better use of obsolete equipment, which is now melted down or put in landfills.
project.title: Bridging the digital divide with computers

project.activities: Volunteer engineers will host workshops that present easy-to-understand concepts about landslide prevention. GVE will host meetings where communities and city engineers can form relationships with officials who are developing mitigation alternatives.

image.title: Community-based landslide awareness in El Salvador

project.longTermImpact: Community participation will result in a project that effectively reduces landslide risks while respecting the concerns of the 5000 families living in the communities.
project.need: In 2001, earthquakes in El Salvador triggered landslides in the Balsam Mountains that destroyed several city blocks of homes and caused over 500 deaths. More than 5000 families live in Nueva San Salvador, an area where landslide disasters could reoccur unless mountain slopes are reinforced. In response, aid agencies have proposed various methods to mitigate risks. GVE's technical support will directly empower community representatives and city engineers to select and manage the alternatives.
project.summary: Enhancing community knowledge to better evaluate documents for mitigating landslide risks through public workshops and to provide focused technical training sessions for Salvadoran engineers.
project.title: Community-based landslide awareness in El Salvador

project.activities: Experienced engineers will conduct workshops that will provide easy-to-understand explanations of technical principles about levee upkeep as a matter of daily routine.

image.title: Community-based flood protection in El Salvador

project.longTermImpact: The project will empower the community's men, women, and children to integrate levee maintenance into their daily lives, which is needed to ensure their livelihood.
project.need: After Hurricane Mitch caused devastating floods, Japan financed the construction of levees to protect community resources and livelihood along the Lempa River. Resources are limited and untrained communities are responsible for all levee maintenance. Without routine upkeep the levees will fall into disrepair, putting hundreds of lives and 27 reconstructed communities at risk of devastation. Communities asked for and will benefit from engineers carefully explaining maintenance technique.
project.summary: Empowering communities through participation in maintenance by raising awareness about the importance of the flood control structures and helping develop specific, appropriate maintenance practices.
project.title: Community-based flood protection in El Salvador

project.activities: Volunteer engineers will inspect water and sanitary facilities at the 10 rural hospitals in Mai Chau, develop schematic plans of each facility, and teach local residents how to maintain the facilities.

image.title: Supporting Health Care in Villages of Vietnam

project.longTermImpact: GVE will provide a detailed evaluation of the strengths and weaknesses of the designs, construction, uses, and local capacity for maintenance. Individual existing system
project.need: Rural hospitals in Mai Chau were unable to support basic medical services because they lacked clean water and sanitary facilities. As a result, health problems, especially illnesses in children and reproductive health in women, continued to worsen. Doctors of the World installed water systems at 10 village hospitals that improved public health rapidly. GVE will provide engineering advice to improve the system design, which DOW needs to better provide public health in other villages of Vietnam.
project.summary: Engineers working with doctors and residents of 10 villages to evaluate the success and lessons learned from potable water and sanitary projects intended to improve rural hospitals and public health.
project.title: Supporting Health Care in Villages of Vietnam

project.activities: Providing much-needed loans to rural poor women in Honduras to start their own businesses.

image.title: Economic Self-Help: Rural Micro Credit

project.longTermImpact: Beneficiaries will be able to raise the standard of living for themselves and their families, by using their profits to eat better food or have access to medicine. After repaying their loans, those funds will be re-loaned to new women.
project.need: Honduras, with 55% unemployment, is the second-poorest country in the Western Hemisphere, behind only Haiti. Although entrepreneurial spirit thrives, for the rural poor, there is absolutely no access to capital. The Adelante Foundation (Adelante is the Spanish word for forward, or progress) is filling the gap, providing much-needed access to capital to the motivated rural poor. Adelante also provides financial training and life skills training to our borrowers.
project.summary: The Adelante Foundation of Honduras will provide micro loans to very poor women in rural Honduras for them to start and grow small businesses. The income will support the woman and her family.
project.title: Economic Self-Help: Rural Micro Credit

project.activities: We will work with local groups, including the Parent Teacher Association to build classrooms and administrative offices. Our partners in Cameroon would execute the plan and would construct the lab on the campus of Tatum High School.

image.title: Science Lab in a Rural High School in Cameroon

project.longTermImpact: The project would result in the first science lab in a high school in the area.
project.need: This high school in Cameroon cannot offer advanced science classes because there is no lab. All science students from the area must seek admission in a larger town, where living is expensive (rent, water, electricity, cooking stove, food, etc.). With a lab, hundreds of students would benefit directly each year. The entire community would benefit by more students staying in the village renting housing, purchasing food and other items.
project.summary: Encouraging students, including girls, to do sciences by providing a science lab in a rural high school. Science education would enable them to become doctors, teachers, and other professionals.
project.title: Science Lab in a Rural High School in Cameroon

project.activities: This program will provide immediate aid by providing each youth with a nutritious meal. It will also provide long-term aid through shared information about nutrition and soy.

image.title: Promoting soy to help alleviate hunger in Malawi

project.longTermImpact: This project will educate Malawians on nutrition and provide the knowledge necessary to survive the famine their nation is currently facing. Pupils will learn the importance of nutrition and how they can grow soy and incorporate it into their diets.
project.need: WCK works to combat hunger in Malawi through an educational nutrition program that teaches youth about the importance of good nutrition. Due to a serious famine in Malawi there is a great need for both sustainable and immediate aid to alleviate hunger in Malawi. Our beneficiaries are Malawian Youth, the staff at each primary school who are all encouraged to share the information with their community. Volunteers also benefit from their first-hand contact with the Malawian people.
project.summary: Youth learn about the benefits of soy and receive a meal with soy. Each meal costs only 75 cents.
project.title: Promoting soy to help alleviate hunger in Malawi

project.activities: This center offers teacher training, English, literacy, math, and computer classes. Skills like sewing and carpet weaving are also taught. Leadership and human rights classes teach women how to assert their rights in a culturally sensitive way.

image.title: Women's Learning Center in Herat, Afghanistan

project.longTermImpact: This project will result in the increased education of Afghan women in the region. The knowledge of income generating skills, as well as leadership skills will help these women to support themselves and their families.
project.need: Herat is the largest city in western Afghanistan and a main trade city for exports. No education has been available to women and girls in Herat for the last decade under the Taliban regime. Recent patterns of civil strife in Afghanistan have destroyed about 95% of the infrastructure and services. Established in September 2002, the Herat Women’s Learning Center serves about 425 women and children, with plans for service expansion during 2003.

organization.mission: The Afghan Institute of Learning (AIL) works to empower all Afghans who are needy, especially women and children, providing them the knowledge and skills to care for themselves. AIL is expanding access to quality education and healthcare through community based programming, enabling communities to develop the capacity of their people. The goal is to create a foundation of quality education and health systems throughout Afghanistan which meet the needs of local people now and in the future. AIL was founded by an Afghan woman and is run mainly by women, reaching thousands each year through health facilities, educational centers and training programs.
organization.name: Afghan Institute of Learning

project.summary: Empowering Afghan women through the provision of education and training opportunities as well as basic health services
project.title: Women's Learning Center in Herat, Afghanistan

project.activities: This center offers teacher training, English, literacy, math, and computer classes. Skills like sewing and carpet weaving are also taught. Leadership and human rights classes teach women how to assert their rights in a culturally sensitive way.

image.title: Women's Learning Center in Mir Bacha Kot

project.longTermImpact: This project will result in the increased education of Afghan women in the region. The knowledge of income generating skills, as well as leadership skills will help these women to support themselves and their families.
project.need: Mir Bacha Kot is a rural community in Afghanistan, north of Kabul. No education has been available to women and girls in Mir Bacha Kot for the last decade under the Taliban regime. Recent patterns of civil strife in Afghanistan have destroyed about 95% of its infrastructure and services. The Mir Bacha Kot Women's Learning Center is currently operating in homes.

organization.mission: The Afghan Institute of Learning (AIL) works to empower all Afghans who are needy, especially women and children, providing them the knowledge and skills to care for themselves. AIL is expanding access to quality education and healthcare through community based programming, enabling communities to develop the capacity of their people. The goal is to create a foundation of quality education and health systems throughout Afghanistan which meet the needs of local people now and in the future. AIL was founded by an Afghan woman and is run mainly by women, reaching thousands each year through health facilities, educational centers and training programs.
organization.name: Afghan Institute of Learning

project.summary: Empowering rural Afghan women through the provision of education and training opportunities as well as basic health services.
project.title: Women's Learning Center in Mir Bacha Kot

project.activities: This center offers teacher training, English, literacy, math, and computer classes. Skills like sewing and carpet weaving are also taught. Leadership and human rights classes teach women how to assert their rights in a culturally sensitive way.

image.title: Women's Learning Centers in Kabul, Afghanistan

project.longTermImpact: This project will result in the increased education of Afghan women in the region. The knowledge of income generating skills, as well as leadership skills will help these women to support themselves and their families.
project.need: Kabul is the capital of Afghanistan. No education has been available to women and girls in Kabul for the last decade under the Taliban regime. Recent patterns of civil strife in Afghanistan have destroyed about 95% of the infrastructure and services. The Kabul Women’s Learning Center serves about 2,000 women and children, with plans for service expansion during 2003.

organization.mission: The Afghan Institute of Learning (AIL) works to empower all Afghans who are needy, especially women and children, providing them the knowledge and skills to care for themselves. AIL is expanding access to quality education and healthcare through community based programming, enabling communities to develop the capacity of their people. The goal is to create a foundation of quality education and health systems throughout Afghanistan which meet the needs of local people now and in the future. AIL was founded by an Afghan woman and is run mainly by women, reaching thousands each year through health facilities, educational centers and training programs.
organization.name: Afghan Institute of Learning

project.summary: Empowering Afghan women through the provision of education and training opportunities as well as basic health services
project.title: Women's Learning Centers in Kabul, Afghanistan

project.activities: This center offers teacher training, English, literacy, math, and computer classes. Skills like sewing and carpet weaving are also taught. Leadership and human rights classes teach women how to assert their rights in a culturally sensitive way.

image.title: Afghan Women's Learning Centers in Peshawar

project.longTermImpact: This project will result in the increased education of Afghan women in the region. The knowledge of income generating skills, as well as leadership skills will help these women to support themselves and their families.
project.need: After the invasion of Afghanistan by Soviet troops in 1979, approximately 8 million people became refugees in Pakistan and Iran. Many relocated in the camps of Pakistan's Northwest frontier Province. These events, and more recent patterns of civil strife in Afghanistan, have completely devastated educational opportunities for Afghans, particularly girls.

organization.mission: Sakena Fund (formerly Creating Hope International) was founded with the vision of bringing hope to victims of war, political unrest, and natural disasters through programs designed to help them rebuild their lives for a brighter tomorrow. CHI's mission is to empower grassroots organizations that provide education, training, and health care to needy people. CHI supports organizations that respond to community needs on an individual level, foster community participation and utilize culturally sensitive education and training.
organization.name: Creating Hope International (CHI)

project.summary: Empowering Afghan women in refugee camps in Peshawar through the provision of education and training opportunities as well as basic health services.
project.title: Afghan Women's Learning Centers in Peshawar

project.activities: Energy healers have been researching the effects of metals and the elements on the health of the human body. CHI plans to hold workshops to train energy healers to utilize various metals and the elements in promoting healthier lifestyles.

image.title: Improving Health by Complementary Health Practices

project.longTermImpact: In these workshops, participants will learn how to help themselves and others through energy healing.
project.need: Americans today expect to live longer than ever before. Unfortunately, increases in life expectancy also mean that people cope with chronic and terminal illnesses for years and even decades. This situation has prompted interest in healing alternatives to complement allopathic medicine. In 2001, Creating Hope International (CHI) began supporting the work of energy healers who have helped and healed many people.

organization.mission: Sakena Fund (formerly Creating Hope International) was founded with the vision of bringing hope to victims of war, political unrest, and natural disasters through programs designed to help them rebuild their lives for a brighter tomorrow. CHI's mission is to empower grassroots organizations that provide education, training, and health care to needy people. CHI supports organizations that respond to community needs on an individual level, foster community participation and utilize culturally sensitive education and training.
organization.name: Creating Hope International (CHI)

project.summary: Opening doors to better health through research and workshops on energy healing as a complementary alternative to allopathic medicine.
project.title: Improving Health by Complementary Health Practices

project.activities: Creating Hope and the Afghan Institute of Learning are expanding University curriculum for Afghan women, and post-secondary courses to train teachers and health care workers.

image.title: Founding an Afghan Women's University

project.longTermImpact: Afghans with skills in Computers and Math are needed to help rebuild the country. Graduates of these programs will be able to work in these fields.
project.need: Due to civil strife in Afghanistan, educational systems for Afghan women have been destroyed. In September 2002, Gawhar Shad University opened in Pakistan to respond to the lack of post-secondary educational opportunities for Afghan women who are high school graduates. Students come from Kabul, Herat, and other cities in Afghanistan.

organization.mission: Sakena Fund (formerly Creating Hope International) was founded with the vision of bringing hope to victims of war, political unrest, and natural disasters through programs designed to help them rebuild their lives for a brighter tomorrow. CHI's mission is to empower grassroots organizations that provide education, training, and health care to needy people. CHI supports organizations that respond to community needs on an individual level, foster community participation and utilize culturally sensitive education and training.
organization.name: Creating Hope International (CHI)

project.summary: Establishing Gawhar Shad University in Peshawar, Pakistan to provide post-secondary education to refugee Afghan women
project.title: Founding an Afghan Women's University

project.activities: To promote women prosperity through credit and economic development.

image.title: WOMAN CENTER: Woman Opportunity MANagement

project.longTermImpact: This project will expand women's participation in local markets &commercial areas by assisting potential Women Entrepreneurs of different social credit groups to own & operate Micro-Enterprises and to develop models based on these experiences.
project.need: The project will affect 2000 women every year with wider outreach impact among 30-35 grassroots NGO Functionaries.
project.notice: Important Notice about Projects in India: We expect that there will be significant delays in getting funds to this project due to new regulatory requirements that impact GlobalGiving's ability to disburse to Indian-banked organizations. GlobalGiving is working hard to address the issue, but there is a chance that we will be unable to disburse funds to this project. If we cannot disburse funds, donations to this project may be reallocated to another organization per our terms and conditions.
project.summary:
A holistic approach to empowering deprived women.
Important Notice about Projects in India: We expect that there will be significant delays in getting funds to this project due to new regulatory requirements that impact GlobalGiving's ability to disburse to Indian-banked organizations. GlobalGiving is working hard to address the issue, but there is a chance that we will be unable to disburse funds to this project. If we cannot disburse funds, donations to this project may be reallocated to another organization per our terms and conditions.
project.title: WOMAN CENTER: Woman Opportunity MANagement

project.activities: To fund the training of health professionals including nurses, psychologists, and social workers, and buy medicine and equipment.

image.title: Improving the Health of Children in Cambodia

project.longTermImpact: This project will help improve the mental and physical health of orphaned children in Cambodia. This project will also ensure the sustainability of the Nutrition Center in Child Mental Health Center.
project.need: Our beneficiaries will be orphaned children suffering from AIDS/HIV and other diseases and children with mental health problems whose parents do not know how to cope because they were deprived of family experiences by the forced separations of the Pol Pot regime. At the Nutrition Center in Phnom Penh, we will help urban orphans from brothels and hospitals that have abandoned them. At the Child Mental Health Center, we will help families, largely the working poor, from all over Cambodia.
project.summary: To help abandoned children, many afflicted with HIV/AIDS, and children with mental health problems. We want to address lack of food, medicine and staff training.
project.title: Improving the Health of Children in Cambodia

project.activities: We offer our own facilities and share our resources for in-service training for government-run school staff so they can implement disability-friendly, inclusive curriculum and practices.

image.title: Accessible education for poor disabled children

project.longTermImpact: To see that all school age children with a physical or mental disability living in poor communities have access to appropriate education designed to meet their specific needs so that every child has a RIGHT to education.
project.need: Although the government mandates the inclusive concept, it is not happening. In low-income areas where children have access to free schools run by the Delhi Government, disabled children are admitted but have no access to therapeutic resources they need nor quality academics, since teachers are not trained to deal with them. Most private schools refuse them admission. Beneficiaries will be the primary school population in about 2,000 government schools.

organization.addressLine1: SAMADHAN'S HUMAN RESOURCE CENTER Pocket 2, Sector 2,
organization.mission: .MISSION STATEMENT: "To establish an infrastructure of accessible services for persons with intellectual disability living in poverty using as far as possible manpower and resources available within target communities, with active community participation, leading to an inclusive society"
organization.name: Samadhan

project.summary: An inclusive education project for disabled and normal children living in poverty provided from our own centers and creating demonstration models in local government schools for possible replication.
project.title: Accessible education for poor disabled children

project.activities: To organize awareness programs, training programs for mothers of children with disabilities, establish a rehabilitation clinic, place trained community workers as home advisors, and to form Self-Help Groups of women and mothers of the disabled.

image.title: Empowered Communities Expand Disability Service

project.longTermImpact: This project will result in communities that are better able to address the needs of those with mental and physical handicaps.
project.need: Poor communities are characterized by lack of access to proper medical care and intervention services for their disabled children, particularly those with mental handicaps. This is compounded by ignorance about mental handicaps. Consequently, needs of children with mental handicaps have not been sufficiently addressed. Beneficiaries are persons with disabilities, specifically those with mental handicaps, and women, particularly mothers of children with mental handicaps.

organization.addressLine1: SAMADHAN'S HUMAN RESOURCE CENTER Pocket 2, Sector 2,
organization.mission: .MISSION STATEMENT: "To establish an infrastructure of accessible services for persons with intellectual disability living in poverty using as far as possible manpower and resources available within target communities, with active community participation, leading to an inclusive society"
organization.name: Samadhan

project.summary: Expanding rehabilitation services from institution to community by creating a body of trained community women leading to transference of responsibilities for the disabled amongst them.
project.title: Empowered Communities Expand Disability Service

project.activities: CHI has helped the leaders of the Bon community write grants to improve their water, sanitary, health, education and living condition. CHI has also provided funds to purchase a milk cow and improve water and living conditions.

image.title: Scholarships for Tibetan Bon Refugee children

project.longTermImpact: CHI is working with Bon leaders to make secondary education possible for the community's children through scholarships. This project will allow 10 children to attend school for one year.
project.need: The Bon are a minority Tibetan ethnic group that fled to India when the Chinese invaded Tibet in 1959. In 1968, the Bon established a community in Dolanji, India on donated land. Today, 75 Tibetan Bon families (including 300 children) are settled there. The community has an orphanage, children's hostel, school (to the 9th class), health center and community farm. Students wishing to continue their studies need scholarships to attend school outside of the community.

organization.mission: Sakena Fund (formerly Creating Hope International) was founded with the vision of bringing hope to victims of war, political unrest, and natural disasters through programs designed to help them rebuild their lives for a brighter tomorrow. CHI's mission is to empower grassroots organizations that provide education, training, and health care to needy people. CHI supports organizations that respond to community needs on an individual level, foster community participation and utilize culturally sensitive education and training.
organization.name: Creating Hope International (CHI)

project.summary: Expanding educational opportunities for Tibetan Bon refugee children in Dolanji, India through scholarships.
project.title: Scholarships for Tibetan Bon Refugee children

project.activities: To set up an extensive network of schools, vocational training programs, shelters, non-formal education centers, a crisis help-line, and scholarships with the aim to assist children in claiming their right to education.

image.title: Alternative school for railway platform children

project.longTermImpact: Outcomes of this project are to make schooling a habit; motivate parents to take charge; make education attainable, useful, and enjoyable for every child; and make children conscious of the role of education in upward social mobility.
project.need: This project will affect around 400 marginalized children living on and around the railway station who have no access to school. The barriers to education for such children arise both from the external environment and from the children's own unique predicament of deprivation. These children are not merely out of school; the very concept of education is unknown to them.
project.notice: Important Notice about Projects in India: We expect that there will be significant delays in getting funds to this project due to new regulatory requirements that impact GlobalGiving's ability to disburse to Indian-banked organizations. GlobalGiving is working hard to address the issue, but there is a chance that we will be unable to disburse funds to this project. If we cannot disburse funds, donations to this project may be reallocated to another organization per our terms and conditions.
project.summary:
Taking the school to the street - advocating for and working with children on issues such as child rights, health care, and nutrition.
Important Notice about Projects in India: We expect that there will be significant delays in getting funds to this project due to new regulatory requirements that impact GlobalGiving's ability to disburse to Indian-banked organizations. GlobalGiving is working hard to address the issue, but there is a chance that we will be unable to disburse funds to this project. If we cannot disburse funds, donations to this project may be reallocated to another organization per our terms and conditions.
project.title: Alternative school for railway platform children

project.activities: Detection of mothers and children "at risk" for developmental delays; to provide intervention to target group of children; to train midwives, health workers, teachers of special education and other professionals in the target community.

image.title: Intervention for avoidable disability

project.longTermImpact: To ensure that all children in the primary school age group with physical or mental disability have available to them appropriate education designed to meet their unique needs as part of the mainstream education provided by schools.
project.need: Lack of access to medical care, ignorance, superstition, limited education, malnutrition and inadequate prenatal care in poor communities result in preventable mental handicap. Government facilities though available are inadequate and erratic. Most of our families are daily wageworkers and cannot afford time to seek services. Beneficiaries are families with disabled offspring, all persons and children with disability, their mothers and the general community.

organization.addressLine1: SAMADHAN'S HUMAN RESOURCE CENTER Pocket 2, Sector 2,
organization.mission: .MISSION STATEMENT: "To establish an infrastructure of accessible services for persons with intellectual disability living in poverty using as far as possible manpower and resources available within target communities, with active community participation, leading to an inclusive society"
organization.name: Samadhan

project.summary: Making professional expertise of a multidisciplinary team accessible for children born with disability, or 'at risk' for developmental delay and mothers 'at risk' within the community.
project.title: Intervention for avoidable disability

project.activities: To train 30 Afghan women as health professionals.

image.title: Training of Afghan Women Health Professionals

project.longTermImpact: Outcomes include lessening the severe shortage of Afghan female health professionals. Graduates of the program will work in clinics for Afghan women and children, examining patients, providing midwifery and nursing services.
project.need: During the last 24 years of war, pressing health needs of 8 million refugees and 10 million in Afghanistan have been unmet, with women and children at most risk. Creating Hope International's project partner, the Afghan Institute of Learning (AIL), has been working to meet the health needs of 100,000 Afghan women and children annually in Afghanistan.

organization.mission: The Afghan Institute of Learning (AIL) works to empower all Afghans who are needy, especially women and children, providing them the knowledge and skills to care for themselves. AIL is expanding access to quality education and healthcare through community based programming, enabling communities to develop the capacity of their people. The goal is to create a foundation of quality education and health systems throughout Afghanistan which meet the needs of local people now and in the future. AIL was founded by an Afghan woman and is run mainly by women, reaching thousands each year through health facilities, educational centers and training programs.
organization.name: Afghan Institute of Learning

project.summary: Improving the health of Afghan families today through health education and investing in a healthier tomorrow for Afghanistan by training women to be health professionals, midwives, and vaccinators
project.title: Training of Afghan Women Health Professionals

project.activities: (a)Create an online database that includes all Congolese NGO's (b)Create an administrative interface that allows organizations to autonomously publish and edit information on their activities and ideas (c)Train organizations to use that interface

image.title: The Internet Portal for Civil Society (CS) in DRC

project.longTermImpact: The project aims to publicize the depth of the Congolese civil society, the extent of its implication in the development of the DRC, and its perspective on the process of democratic transition that is now in progress.
project.need: In DRC, NGO's find themselves responsible in nearly all social sectors. In parallel, they are promoting human rights, peace and democracy. The importance of communication in development work does not have to be proved, but still today, Congolese NGO's with Internet visibility are rare. Beneficiaries of the proposed program are therefore, primarily, all Congolese.
project.summary: To allow Congolese CS organizations to get a dynamic Internet visibility through a Portal where organizations will present themselves, autonomously, as well as there activities and perspectives.
project.title: The Internet Portal for Civil Society (CS) in DRC

project.activities: To elaborate the policy of the Curriculum for the teacher training program of the Intercultural Bilingual Preschool Teachers based on the specialty for the educational development of the indigenous people of the Peruvian Amazon.

image.title: Intercultural Bilingual Education-preschool level

project.longTermImpact: The education for preschool-level indigenous children of the Peruvian Amazon will be improved.
project.need: The first five years is fundamental for the development of children. At this age, children develop their basic personality traits as well as the capacities and attitudes that enable them to encounter the future lessons. This project intends to improve the education for preschool level. It will benefit the indigenous women who will be formed as Intercultural Bilingual Preschool Teachers and indirectly it will benefit the children of the indigenous communities of the Amazon.
project.summary: Elaboration of the policies of the Curriculum for the education of indigenous women in the specialty of intercultural bilingual teachers for preschool level.
project.title: Intercultural Bilingual Education-preschool level

project.activities: We plan to expand on our initial work in Guatemala, conducting training and site visits with local groups to assist them in using Martus to protect the security of their records.

image.title: Martus Human Rights Bulletin System - Guatemala

project.longTermImpact: To help the process of reconciliation and accountability for human rights abuses that must take place Guatemala, where many human rights abuses from the long civil war (which ended in 1996) remain unprosecuted.
project.need: Violation information gathered by grassroots human rights groups is currently being lost to confiscation, destruction or neglect, reducing their effectiveness and making it difficult for prosecutors, truth commissions and international NGOs to use the evidence to hold perpetrators of human rights abuses accountable. The situation is particularly severe in Guatemala, where local NGOs face increasingly pervasive threats, abuse and theft, as reported by Human Rights Watch and others.
project.summary: Introducing Martus - a new technology tool to assist grassroots human rights workers worldwide to collect, safeguard and disseminate information on human rights abuses - to NGOs in Guatemala.
project.title: Martus Human Rights Bulletin System - Guatemala

project.activities: To purchase and scan 100 books that have been requested by teachers and parents. Ten of these will be textbooks that will be proofread for perfect text accuracy. All 100 will be shared nationwide through the Bookshare.org online collection.

image.title: Accessible Books for Students with Disabilities

project.longTermImpact: This project will help to develop a core collection of K-12 books to serve students with disabilities.
project.need: Fewer than 5% of books are produced in formats that are accessible to people who have visual or learning disabilities. To read other books, more than three million US residents, including one million students, are forced to laboriously scan them into computers. In particular, K-12 students need accessible textbooks and outside reading material. Schools are legally required to offer textbooks in these formats, but access is often inadequate and little supplemental reading is made available.
project.summary: Adding more accessible textbooks and supplemental reading material for K-12 students with visual and learning disabilities to the Bookshare.org online collection.
project.title: Accessible Books for Students with Disabilities

project.activities: To expand the services of the medical clinic to each of Kibera's eleven villages, and to purchase land for permanent establishment of the Rye Medical Clinic and CFK offices to ensure sustainability.

image.title: Carolina for Kibera, Inc.

project.longTermImpact: Outcomes include using sports as a method of promoting community development, AIDS awareness, and ethno-religious cooperation and creating a safe space for youth to develop leadership skills.
project.need: Kibera, the largest slum in East Africa, has a history of ethnic tension. Over 600,000 people do not receive basic services such as water, healthcare, education, or sewage disposal. Over 80% of all youth are unemployed, nearly 20% are HIV positive, and the slum has been the source of two violent clashes between ethnic groups over the past ten years. CFK established three core projects to help address these needs in Kibera: a youth sports association, Rye Clinic, and Binti Pamoja Center.

organization.addressLine1: FedEx Global Education Center UNC-Chapel Hill Campus Box 5145
organization.mission:
CFK's mission is develop local leaders, catalyze positive change and alleviate poverty in the Kibera slum of Nairobi.
CFK envisions a Kibera where people are healthy, safe and self-sufficient. A place where every person, regardless of background, has a voice in his or her future and access to opportunities and resources to realize that future. A community that finds strength in diversity and individuals who are empowered to pursue opportunities both locally and across the globe.
organization.name: Carolina for Kibera, Inc.

project.summary: Preventing ethnic conflict and promoting participatory development through youth-led service and athletic opportunities and access to a primary care clinic, library, and AIDS peer education.
project.title: Carolina for Kibera, Inc.

project.activities: To create a series of comic books dealing with disabilities issues in order to create awareness about disability and, in particular, mental handicap.

image.title: Narrative Art for Education on Disability

project.longTermImpact: The outcome will be to help inculcate correct attitudes towards persons with mental handicap and disability in general by creating awareness and sensitization to difficulties they face.
project.need: Lack of information about disability in India in general and among the uneducated superstition creates a perpetual situation of deprivation for the mentally handicapped and their families and prevents improvement in their life style. Investing in a medium, which has potential to reach a large readership and lends itself to a variety of uses, paves the way for equal opportunities and acceptance by family and society. Beneficiaries are all disabled, their families, and workers in this field.

organization.addressLine1: SAMADHAN'S HUMAN RESOURCE CENTER Pocket 2, Sector 2,
organization.mission: .MISSION STATEMENT: "To establish an infrastructure of accessible services for persons with intellectual disability living in poverty using as far as possible manpower and resources available within target communities, with active community participation, leading to an inclusive society"
organization.name: Samadhan

project.summary: The series of comic books is designed to educate, sensitize and reach both the illiterate and educated, adults and children contributing to a better world for the mentally handicapped and disabled.
project.title: Narrative Art for Education on Disability

project.activities: To use theatre as a medium of social change, through visual, performing arts and drama therapy in work with the disabled, their mothers and community women by training a core group of workers to carry out the project.

image.title: Using theatre for social change

project.longTermImpact: This project will result in the development of study and research programs for national and international students in a "hands-on experiential training opportunity" into the transference of drama therapy techniques into the cultural idioms of India.
project.need: We have not harnessed the power of theatre as a tool for social change. Reaching out to a heterogeneous mix of people needs a medium, which will address diversity yet evoke positive responses. Theatre and the performing arts as positive contribution for education and work with marginalized groups are as yet unaccepted. Research will provide rich material for global sharing. Beneficiaries are all those working with empowerment of women, the disabled and theatre arts.

organization.addressLine1: SAMADHAN'S HUMAN RESOURCE CENTER Pocket 2, Sector 2,
organization.mission: .MISSION STATEMENT: "To establish an infrastructure of accessible services for persons with intellectual disability living in poverty using as far as possible manpower and resources available within target communities, with active community participation, leading to an inclusive society"
organization.name: Samadhan

project.summary: Providing training in a series of workshops in the use of theatre arts and finding culturally appropriate solutions for problems faced by the disabled and women, leading to positive social change.
project.title: Using theatre for social change

project.activities: To compile information nationally and globally, set up an online service for the computer literate and initiate a multilevel approach for the semiliterate and uneducated, which will use seminars, publications, puppet theatre and more.

image.title: Web-based resources for mental handicap

project.longTermImpact: Others will be better educated about disability in general and mental handicap in particular, causing improvement in services, greater opportunities for learning, and sharing of experiences.
project.need: India has expertise in information technology but no centralized source for information on disability or data on our diverse cultures and traditional knowledge. Communication systems are not designed to suit our needs. Successful work within the country goes unreported, preventing improvement in services, loss of opportunities for learning, and sharing our own experiences. Beneficiaries are all disability activists, NGO's, governments, service providers and consumers.

organization.addressLine1: SAMADHAN'S HUMAN RESOURCE CENTER Pocket 2, Sector 2,
organization.mission: .MISSION STATEMENT: "To establish an infrastructure of accessible services for persons with intellectual disability living in poverty using as far as possible manpower and resources available within target communities, with active community participation, leading to an inclusive society"
organization.name: Samadhan

project.summary: To compile and disseminate web based information about mental handicap primarily and later other disabilities for national and international service seekers.
project.title: Web-based resources for mental handicap

project.activities: Activites include providing high quality community-based reproductive health care services, and training in women's leadership and organization.

image.title: Organizing Women to Improve Health in India

project.longTermImpact: Reduce unwanted pregnancies and increase average spacing between wanted births; Increase percent of women obtaining pre-natal care and assistance at birth by a trained health professional; Increase credit provided to women's group members
project.need: In densely populated Bihar, over 70% of the people live in poverty. Most belong to socially marginalized castes. Women are especially disadvantaged. Only 11% of women are literate. Many girls marry before they are 18. Women suffer from lack of maternal health care, unwanted pregnancies, and closely spaced births. They lack vital health knowledge and have a limited role in decision-making. Women do not have a chance meet to discuss how to solve their priority problems.
project.summary: To help 10,500 poor, marginalized women in 35 rural villages in Bihar, India organize self-help groups, escape money lenders, increase income, manage their savings, improve their health and education.
project.title: Organizing Women to Improve Health in India

project.activities: The project includes programs providing food, health, education and training, and engaging women in income-generating activities.

image.title: Empowering Youth with Disabilities in Colombia

project.longTermImpact: This project takes an entrepreneurial approach to empower and integrate youth with special needs and their families into the Bogota community, thus achieving sustainable growth, as expressed in their own voices.
project.need: In Bogota, disability often leads to isolation and lack of integration to family and community. In extreme poverty, there is limited access to health and education. This program directly benefits 2000 people in a community of 15,000, including 200 youth with special needs.
project.summary: A holistic approach that provides training for the development and integration of families and children with special needs into their communities.
project.title: Empowering Youth with Disabilities in Colombia

project.activities: Activities include weekly training meetings, research, and interaction with business leaders.

image.title: Empowering Youth Through Social Entrepreneurship

project.longTermImpact: This project will implement and manage volunteer initiatives designed to help young people develop entrepreneurial and creative skills that will allow them to address local social needs and improve their own situations.
project.need: Young Initiative targets the large percentage of children ages 12-18 who live in poverty and lack a place in society where they can participate in a positive way. YI offers them a way to express their needs, develop their abilities, and contribute to society.
project.summary: Young Initiative (YI) seeks to turn volunteering into an opportunity for poor youth in Brazil, Uruguay, and Argentina to become committed citizens and entrepreneurs in local social initiatives.
project.title: Empowering Youth Through Social Entrepreneurship

project.activities: a) Surveys to support integral land use planning; b) Collaboration to gather all regional actors; c) Training program to provide communities with skills on restoration, production and social improvement; d) Disseminating and communicating the process

image.title: Conserving the Oaxaca City Watershed in Mexico

project.longTermImpact: The outcome will be to an attained balance between human needs and nature protection.
project.need: The San Felipe Mountains provide most of the city's water, regulate the climate of the region, harbor a rich nature, and provide the livelihood of several rural communities. However, deforestation, urban growth, and water and soil contamination all threaten the mountains and their historical inhabitants. It is urgent that we protect the watershed and improve the quality of life of its inhabitants.
project.summary: This project delivers information, planning, training, and collaborative cornerstones for the long-term conservation of the San Felipe Mountains.
project.title: Conserving the Oaxaca City Watershed in Mexico

project.activities: An innovative tutorial program that assists intellectually endowed students in reviewing basic concepts taught in grades 5-8, in response to an urgent need to aid youth with the knowledge necessary to compete in a technology-based global marketplace.

image.title: PACTO: Technical School Prep for Brazilian Youth

project.longTermImpact: This project will successfully prepare students for entrance exams for technical schools through competent teaching and motivation.
project.need: In Brazil poor adolescents are locked out of the best publicly-funded technical schools because their neighborhood schools do not adequately prepare them to take the competitive exams required for admission. These technical schools that grant degrees in accounting, biochemistry, and information technology represent a crucial leap into an improved social and economic level. PACTO aims to help these youth set educational and professional goals and provide the means to reach them and go beyond.
project.summary: A tutorial program that prepares poor adolescents for entering publicly-funded technical schools.
project.title: PACTO: Technical School Prep for Brazilian Youth

project.activities: To realize our objectives, we take on the following activities: marketing, awareness raising, product acquisition, certification, support to Trademark users, institutionalization of FTTSA, research and advocacy, and project management and monitoring.

image.title: Fair Trade in Tourism South Africa (FTTSA)

project.longTermImpact: We seek to aid socio-economic transformation in South Africa through the promotion and implementation of Fair Trade in Tourism principles and the award of a special label that certifies compliance with these principles and related criteria
project.need: We target established tourism businesses and newer entrants into the industry, including community-based projects and entrepreneurs previously excluded from the formal economy. Both target groups benefit from a "stamp of approval" and related marketing opportunities, and from knowing that they are contributing to socio-economic change in South Africa. Tourists and tour operators also benefit by being able to choose good quality, fairly operated products for inclusion in travel itineraries.
project.summary: We promote equitable and sustainable tourism in South Africa primarily by awarding a special 'fair trade' label to qualifying businesses.
project.title: Fair Trade in Tourism South Africa (FTTSA)

project.activities: To create a network of Solidary Popular Enterprises & to introduce them to the formal business sector as strategic partners, and to provide SPEs with administrative, financial & technological aid through a Shared Services Unit.

image.title: From Poverty to Self-Sufficiency in Colombia

project.longTermImpact: To democratize business knowledge through a Bank of Talent Donors, which transfers knowledge from the formal business sector to SPEs. To create a Systemic Model of solutions to unemployment/poverty problems.
project.need: The high unemployment rate (15.8%) in Cali, Colombia drastically affects poor Afro-Colombian women living in the Aguablanca (Cali’s poorest and most excluded area). These women, the beneficiaries of our project, are unemployed, earn less than US$1 a day from informal tasks, and are discriminated against for their black ethnicity. We aim to create small associated enterprises that generate income and receive training and business knowledge from the formal business sector.
project.summary: To create a network of enterprises for the poor introduced to the formal business sector and managed by a shared service.
project.title: From Poverty to Self-Sufficiency in Colombia

project.activities: Survival support (food, shelter, clothing, treatment, education, legal, etc.) to 20 children and establishment of community-based preventive mechanism for fostering the process of sustainable reintegration.

image.title: Community Based Reintegration Support to Survivors

project.longTermImpact: A comprehensive community-based reintegration process will be created to save 40 trafficked children - victims of exploitative employment or prostitution - from stigma.
project.need:
Bangladeshi culture sees children as passive and controlled by adults. The understanding and awareness of child rights is almost non-existent. Combined with social mores of hiding experiences of physical/mental abuse and coerced into silence by the abusing adults and their protectors. In order to save the children from the stigma a comprehensive community based reintegration process is required.
Beneficiaries: 40 trafficked children, victims of exploitative employment or prostitution.
project.summary: Community based sustainable reintegration support to survivors of trafficking and exploited child labor by BNWLA.
project.title: Community Based Reintegration Support to Survivors

project.activities: This project aims to organize a pilot village in the rural zone of the municipality of Viotá, with the participation of 100 families, including those who have been displaced by the lifting of tariff barriers and political violence.

image.title: FURALCAMP: Generating Income in Rural Colombia

project.longTermImpact: The project will re-educate and re-adjust 100 familes to rural life in individual and collective schemes covering housing, employment and food production.
project.need: The program helps to generate employment for all family members, combating problems such as juvenile delinquency, prostitution and drug addiction. To implement our plans we require a "Seed Capital," which enables us to buy land, settle educational programs, perform infrastructure works and develop production projects. The people who the project benefits are retired workers, elderly and unemployed peasants, and families displaced by political violence.
project.summary: A pilot program that seeks to bring workers and former peasant families into integrated services, in order to prevent the exodus to the big cities.
project.title: FURALCAMP: Generating Income in Rural Colombia

project.activities: Training teachers, enhancing school curriculum, promoting the participation of parents, and strengthening ties between the children and their communities in Peru.

image.title: URPICHALLAY: Improving Rural Schools in Peru

project.longTermImpact: The goal of the project is to help improve the quality of rural education. Urpichallay has been working with the poorest rural schools for 11 years in cooperation with the Ministry of Education.
project.need: The majority of rural schools in Peru are located far from cities, and as a result they lack sufficient attention from the government. This neglect leads to a number of problems, such as deficient infrastructure and educational materials, inadequate teacher preparation, and separation of children from their communities and culture. The beneficiaries are 12 schools, 48 teachers, 1600 students and 720 parents from 5 rural communities.
project.summary: Help improve the quality of education in rural schools with teachers, children, and the farming community.
project.title: URPICHALLAY: Improving Rural Schools in Peru

project.activities: Creating support services, sensitivity activities, and educational resources to expand the Adolescent Fathers’ Support Center, whose mission is to educate professionals working with adolescents about the importance of adolescent fatherhood

image.title: PAPAI: Educating Adolescent Fathers in Brazil

project.longTermImpact: To help boys be responsible for their reproductive lives and to help girls involve their child’s father in the nurturing process.
project.need: In Brazil, little attention has been given to men’s participation in matters related to contraception, pregnancy, childcare, and prevention of STDs/AIDS. Our programs target low-income communities in the Metropolitan area of Recife/PE-Brazil, where adolescent pregnancy and motherhood in the last 20 years have caused much concern amongst specialists and government officials.
project.summary: Addressing the issue of adolescent pregnancy in a positive way by creating programs that educate young fathers about pregnancy, infant care, and fatherhood.
project.title: PAPAI: Educating Adolescent Fathers in Brazil

project.activities: 1) Workshops 2) Multimedia production 3) Biobank promotion and display in each community 4) Development of new input/output channels 4) Maintenance of the infrastructure

image.title: Youth-Led Technological Solutions in Uruguay

project.longTermImpact: Maintenance of a complete digital memory of the sustainable development processes that we initiate in each community 2) Maintenance and development of all output channels, promoting the replicability of each showcased material in other communities
project.need: Needs: To develop citizens' community participation. Revision and actualization of our technical infrastructure. Direct beneficiaries: The formal and non-formal educative system; Families and neighbors in each community. Indirect beneficiaries: Communities and individuals that access BIOBANK all over the world.
project.summary: Multimedia memory showcasing community-based sustainable development processes, catalyzed by youth.
project.title: Youth-Led Technological Solutions in Uruguay

project.activities: To produce a film that will tell stories of victims of human rights abuses, including women and environmental activists, who courageously confronted state violators but have not yet received justice.

image.title: Documentary on Human Rights Abuses in Africa

project.longTermImpact: To mobilize audiences to demand justice for victims of human rights abuses in Africa, and to pressure governments to create an African Human Rights Court.
project.need: Need: To educate the public on African human rights. To mobilize the population to establish an African Court to end impunity and bring justice to victims of human rights abuses. Beneficiaries: Victims of human rights abuses in Africa who need compensation for their suffering. An overall increase in the respect of human rights will foster development, stability, and economic growth, and thus will benefit the entire African continent.
project.summary: Production and distribution of film that will show the need to establish an effective African Court.
project.title: Documentary on Human Rights Abuses in Africa

project.activities: To develop mechanisms that support youth self-employment and the active participation of youth in the social and economic development of Paraguay.

image.title: Promoting Youth Self-Employment in Paraguay

project.longTermImpact: To strengthen the capacities of juvenile entrepreneurship and to develop mechanisms that support youth self-employment and the active participation of youth in the social and economic development of Paraguay.
project.need: Young Paraguayans are the most affected by unemployment, by the lack of quality in their formal education, by the deficiencies in public health services, and by incomplete access to basic sanitation, drinking water, electricity and physical and social infrastructure. This project will benefit approximately 260 young people who participate in the project’s process of technical habilitation.
project.summary: To help develop self-employment initiatives as an answer to the increasing labor demand in the youth population and to contribute to the social and economic development of Paraguay.
project.title: Promoting Youth Self-Employment in Paraguay

project.activities: CAT hopes to create classrooms where students participate more actively in learning by improve instruction for 750 additional students through working with 25 more teachers in 2004.

image.title: Workshop in the Art of Teaching

project.longTermImpact: Create an atmosphere where teachers spend less time maintaining discipline and more time teaching, where teachers teach students to think critically and solve problems, and finally, where children feel safe and can focus on learning.
project.need: A child's success in life depends to a great extent on the quality of education the child receives. This is especially true for children living in impoverished communities. Center for Artistry in Teaching is reengineering the way teachers see themselves and the way they teach - to include their total mind, heart, and body, while incorporating spontaneity, critical thinking, and problem solving. The result is a re-energized educator who engages in the art of teaching.
project.summary: The quality of a child's teachers has an enormous impact on that child's chances for success in life. The Workshop in the Art of Teaching improves the effectiveness of teachers.
project.title: Workshop in the Art of Teaching

project.activities: Create a show about discrimination and intolerance. Develop an educational book accompanied by a demonstrative video about theatre and group games to use in education and social work.

image.title: Education Through Theatre in Mexico

project.longTermImpact: To offer training, consultation, and didactic material to teachers, artistic groups, and persons linked to social, educational, and cultural activities. To sensitize children, teacher, and parents to various themes.
project.need: Need: The problem is not only a lack of good technique but also a lack of the right attitude and criteria. Grupo 55 considers human growth to be as important as professional growth. We aim to train people who can and will work in a team, who are willing to learn to listen and generate consensus, and who will teach and direct through suggestion and motivation. Beneficaries: Thousands of children, teachers, artists, parents, and NGOs.
project.summary: Offer original training programs, consulting, plays and didactic material to improve the arts, education and social work.
project.title: Education Through Theatre in Mexico

project.activities: 5-month training courses on learning a special methodology to help discharge emotional burdens that often lead to abuse, provided to teachers, social workers, psychologists, and all people working with children.

image.title: Child Abuse Advocacy in Mexico

project.longTermImpact: This project aims to transform the culture of abuse against children and women in Mexico.
project.need: The need to transform the culture of abuse against children and women is urgent in Mexico. These people live in a violent environment where the lack of money is one of the many factors that make people feel depressed. Children and women are often the target when this frustration has to be discharged. There are very few public services to help low-income families when abuse problems arise in the home. The only public Mental Health Hospital that existed in Mexico City has been closed.
project.summary: Creating materials and supporting several spaces where professionals working with children can be trained and families can receive attention dealing with abuse (physical, emotional, or sexual).
project.title: Child Abuse Advocacy in Mexico

project.activities: This project covers 3 years of education fees, including school supplies, two school outfits, and a nutritious meal every school day at Wend-Kouni public school in Sabou.

image.title: PENGDWENDE: Educating Orphans in Burkina Faso

project.longTermImpact: Many orphaned children will be able to attend school through this project. After each school term, Pengwendé will evaluate each sponsored child, and will document the project’s progress on the website and through emails
project.need: Many Burkinabe parents would like their children to go to school, but the cost of education (the education fee, school stationary, clothes, and nourishment) often becomes a burden on the family. The burden becomes heavier when a family also needs to foster a dependent fatherless or motherless child. This explains why many children have had to quit school very early and are now illiterate.
project.summary: Pengdwende helps children that are fatherless and/or motherless to attend a free primary school.
project.title: PENGDWENDE: Educating Orphans in Burkina Faso

project.activities: To professionalize courses for 160 mothers. The courses include theoretical notions, demonstration, and on-the-job training. Acquisition of sewing equipment: machines, material for everyday use, and kits for the graduates.

image.title: Job Training for Poor Mothers in Brazil

project.longTermImpact: To help bring mothers into the formal job market.
project.need: Some mothers need social assistance, guidance, material and technical skills to make them competitive professionals. Once these mothers become professionals, they will be able to get into the formal job market and generate income. We will offer 160 vacancies for several courses: hairdressing, manicure, painting on material, sewing, and computer courses. This project is meant to last for one year.

organization.mission: Dara Institute is a civil society organization that works to promote health and human development by implementing and promoting an integrated multidisciplinary approach to fight poverty. A world pioneer in intersectoral work with social determinants of health, it was founded by Dr. Vera Cordeiro, in 1991, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Our objective is to contribute to changing the health and human development framework in society, incorporating an integrated multisectoral approach to fight poverty. For the 8th consecutive year, SC ranked best NGO in Latin America and 21st in the world, according to NGO Advisor, a Swiss publication.
organization.name: Instituto Dara

project.summary: To help mothers generate income and to promote self-sufficiency by developing important professional skills.
project.title: Job Training for Poor Mothers in Brazil
